title: Teen caught own jaw when it was ripped off in riding accident
text:
Emily Eccles suffered some of the worst facial injuries doctors had ever seen outside of a war zone (Picture: PA)

A teenager was left holding her jaw in her hands as it hung from her face after a horrendous riding accident.

Emily Eccles, 15, had just one centimetre of skin keeping her jaw to the rest of her head after her horse got spooked by an exhaust popping on a car and smashed into a gatepost.

She suffered some of the worst facial injuries doctors had ever seen outside of a war zone and believed her life would be changed forever.

But thanks to the work of one talented facial reconstructive surgeon, she has made a ‘miraculous recovery’ in just two months.

Emily says she remembers catching something red which flashed in front of her face as she fell during the incident on a country path near Baslow in Derbyshire in August.

Advertisement

She said: ‘I just looked down and I was like, ‘I don’t know what that is’.’

Once in the ambulance, she ‘could see teeth and bone and said, ‘is that my jaw?’.’

Holding the bottom of her face in her own hands, she was rushed to Sheffield Children’s Hospital where consultant facial reconstructive surgeon Ricardo Mohammed-Ali rebuilt her face in a five-and-a-half hour long operation.

The teenager held her jaw in her hands as she was taken to the hospital (Picture: PA)

A pre-operation CT Scan 3D Image of Emily’s injuries (Picture: PA)

Consultant facial reconstructive surgeon Ricardo Mohammed-Ali rebuilt Emily’s face (Picture: PA)

Mr Mohammed-Ali pieced together Emily’s face using three titanium plates and more than 160 stitches and managed to save all but one of her teeth.

The teen, who is studying for her GCSEs at Wales High School in Sheffield, said her friends thought her injuries made her look like a ‘zombie’.

She tried not to look at first, but saw her appearance when she accidentally switched on her selfie camera .

She said: ‘It was like something you see in a film, it was really quite horrific.

‘At first I was thinking, I don’t know what I’m going to do, I’m not going to look like me, I’m not going to have the same kind of life as I did before.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

However, two months on from her operation, her scars are fading by the day and she has been back at school for a month.

The fearless teen is keen to start riding again, but has to convince her mum Michelle, 50, and dad Chris, 48, first before climbing on another horse.

Emily thought her life and appearance were changed forever (Picture: PA)

Two months after the operation, the teenager’s scars are fading by the day (Picture: PA)

Mr Mohammed-Ali says in a year’s time, ‘from speaking distance, you won’t even be able to tell that anything’s happened’.

Emily says she ‘can’t thank him enough’ and has written to the Queen to ask her to grant him a knighthood.

She said: ‘Everything that he’s done in his career up to that point led up to him being on call that night.

‘If anything had gone any differently, I might not have had a bottom jaw.’

Tory lord wearing just a dressing gown and slippers takes on Extinction Rebellion

She added: ‘Saving people’s lives and getting them back to normality definitely deserves some sort of recognition.’

The 15-year-old has received a personal letter from the Queen’s secretary saying her recommendation has been referred to the relevant body.

Amazingly, Emily went back to school a month after her operation (Picture: PA)

She is now campaigning for Mr Mohammed-Ali to receive a knighthood (Picture: PA)

Mr Mohammed-Ali said he was ‘extremely pleased’ with Emily’s recovery so far.

Advertisement

He said: ‘It could have been worse, but it is one of the most significant injuries that I have seen in a child outside of areas of conflict.

‘Emily’s injury was significant in that the entire left side of her lower jaw from the front of the jaw to the joint was pulled away from the face and only retained by a small strip of skin.

‘The nerves that supply sensation to the lip and chin was torn on both sides. Branches of the facial nerve that move the muscles of the lower lip were severed on both sides.

‘The lower part of Emily’s face was only attached by a piece of skin.’
